awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for the Conference on File and Storage Technologies 2025 (FAST '25) and Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation 2025(NSDI '25)
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Association presents conferences at the forefront of computing innovation and research that build collaborations between researchers and practitioners from industry, government, and academia. These events provide educational, mentorship, and networking opportunities of very high value to graduate students in the computer sciences who attend. To help increase the representation and participation of these students, this proposal provides funding to assist approximately 20-35 US-based graduate students to attend each of the following events:

23rd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST 2025)
22nd USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 2025)

The knowledge shared and advanced at these conferences has practical and meaningful application to many tools used in daily life, as well as to the ethical, cultural, and social ramifications of computing technology. This grant allows the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. USENIX is an open access organization, and all research and results presented and published at these events are freely available to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
USENIX Association: FAST/NSDI ‘25 Project Outcomes Report

This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in 2025, specifically the 23rd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST ‘25) and the 22nd Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI ‘25). 

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work. This grant made possible the participation of graduate-level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers. 

FAST ‘25 took place February 25-27, 2025, in Santa Clara, California. It brought together storage-system researchers and practitioners to explore new directions in the design, implementation, evaluation, and deployment of storage systems. NSDI ‘25 took place April 28-30, 2025, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. NSDI ‘25 focused on the design principles, implementation, and practical evaluation of networked and distributed systems. Both events consisted of technical presentations, including refereed papers and poster sessions. 

Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, mentorship opportunities, poster sessions, and receptions. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) travel expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code for the full cost of conference registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with the costs of travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the number of nights they requested for lodging. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before disbursing the payments. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,

  • Conference participation, e.g., presenting a paper or a poster,

  • Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research,

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,

  • Attendance at institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,

  • Class level, prioritizing graduate-level students, and 

  • Financial need.

The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for FAST ‘25 and NSDI ‘25. This support was instrumental in enabling a total of 37 grants for students to participate in FAST ‘25 and NSDI ‘25, which we anticipate will make a significant difference in their academic and professional development.

  • For FAST ‘25, USENIX received 24 grant applications from students and awarded 20 grants. The NSF funds of $16,450 covered 10 of these grants. We had initially selected 12 recipients for NSF funding, but one declined their grant at the last minute, and another did not attend FAST ‘25, and so we revoked both grants. Unfortunately, this happened too late in the process to award those resources to new grantees. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university, and those who flew to the venue traveled on a US carrier. There were 208 attendees at FAST ‘25, which included at least 32 students. 

  • For NSDI ‘25, USENIX received 45 grant applications from students and awarded 43 grants.  The NSF funds of $33,550 covered 27 of these grants. The funds remaining after FAST ‘25 grants were paid enabled us to cover more grants for NSDI ‘25 than would have otherwise been possible. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. The recipients who were not local traveled on a US carrier. There were 271 attendees at NSDI ‘25, which included 76 students.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2025
Modified by: Catherine Bergman

por.por_txt_cntn:
USENIX Association: FAST/NSDI 25 Project Outcomes Report


This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in 2025, specifically the 23rd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST 25) and the 22nd Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 25).


Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work. This grant made possible the participation of graduate-level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers.


FAST 25 took place February 25-27, 2025, in Santa Clara, California. It brought together storage-system researchers and practitioners to explore new directions in the design, implementation, evaluation, and deployment of storage systems. NSDI 25 took place April 28-30, 2025, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. NSDI 25 focused on the design principles, implementation, and practical evaluation of networked and distributed systems. Both events consisted of technical presentations, including refereed papers and poster sessions.


Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, mentorship opportunities, poster sessions, and receptions.


Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) travel expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code for the full cost of conference registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with the costs of travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the number of nights they requested for lodging. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before disbursing the payments.


The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:




Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,




Conference participation, e.g., presenting a paper or a poster,




Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicants research,




Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,




Attendance at institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,




Class level, prioritizing graduate-level students, and




Financial need.




The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for FAST 25 and NSDI 25. This support was instrumental in enabling a total of 37 grants for students to participate in FAST 25 and NSDI 25, which we anticipate will make a significant difference in their academic and professional development.




For FAST 25, USENIX received 24 grant applications from students and awarded 20 grants. The NSF funds of $16,450 covered 10 of these grants. We had initially selected 12 recipients for NSF funding, but one declined their grant at the last minute, and another did not attend FAST 25, and so we revoked both grants. Unfortunately, this happened too late in the process to award those resources to new grantees. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university, and those who flew to the venue traveled on a US carrier. There were 208 attendees at FAST 25, which included at least 32 students.






For NSDI 25, USENIX received 45 grant applications from students and awarded 43 grants. The NSF funds of $33,550 covered 27 of these grants. The funds remaining after FAST 25 grants were paid enabled us to cover more grants for NSDI 25 than would have otherwise been possible. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. The recipients who were not local traveled on a US carrier. There were 271 attendees at NSDI 25, which included 76 students.
